description:
http://business.uoregon.edu/ug/minors/entrepreneurship
The minor in entrepreneurship is intended for nonbusiness students who want to learn about innovation processes and the managerial and leadership skills required to create a new venture. The entrepreneurship minor gives students the opportunity to envision, develop, test, and build a for-profit or nonprofit venture working within an interdisciplinary framework of exploration and self-discovery.
The minor in entrepreneurship is open to students from all majors except pre-business, business administration, or accounting. For general social sciences majors with a concentration in applied economics, business, and society, students must adhere to the GSS double-dipping policy. See theGSS websitefor more information. Completing the minor requires 24 credits of course work, which can be completed in one academic year.
It is possible to earn more than one minor within the Lundquist College of Business. However, for students earning more than one business-related minor, no more than three courses can be used to satisfy multiple business minors.
Students may declare a minor in entrepreneurship online at the college’swebsite, where a checklist of requirements can be found. Advising assistance is available in the Office of Undergraduate Advising.
additional_program_info:
Students who take BA 215 instead of ACTG 340 will be required to take one upper-division elective course.
It is possible to earn more than one minor within the Lundquist College of Business. However, for students earning more than one business-related minor, no more than three courses can be used to satisfy multiple business minors. Please see an advisor for more details.

courses.title: Introduction to Business
courses.description: Presents an integrated view of both established and entrepreneurial businesses by studying their common characteristics and processes in a global context. Introduces theory and develops basic skills in the areas of accounting, finance, management, and marketing, with an emphasis on social responsibility and ethical practices. Explores how businesses can create value for themselves and society by addressing environmental and social challenges.

courses.title: Launching New Ventures
courses.description: Skills, behaviors, and knowledge necessary for creating and growing new ventures. Evaluating opportunities, developing growth strategies, obtaining venture financing, intellectual property, and building a management team.

courses.title: Entrepreneurial Marketing
courses.description: Techniques for analyzing and developing new markets. Pricing, communicating, and distributing new products or services with limited resources. Developing marketing plans for new ventures.

courses.title: Accounting for Entrepreneurs
courses.description: Sources and uses of cash in the context of start-up and small firms. Emphasis on cash generated by operations and used for operations and growth. Secondary emphasis on external sources of cash.

courses.title: Introduction to Architecture
courses.description: Offers a structure of principles for making places for people. Examines places, design procedures, and the use of archtiectural principles in general.

courses.title: Design Skills
courses.description: Introduction to basic design processes, methods, and media.

courses.title: Introduction to Architectural Computer Graphics
courses.description: Introduces basic skills and literacy with the computer for architectural illustration, drafting, and design.

courses.title: Understanding Contemporary Art
courses.description: Examine contemporary art concepts, approaches and themes. Understand how to interpret contemporary artwork and contextualize arts’ relationship to culture, society and life today.

courses.title: The Artist Experience
courses.description: Explore concepts defining contemporary art through the individual studio practice of art faculty. Artist presentations will examine their creative process, influences, professional experiences and career.

courses.title: Surface, Space, and Time
courses.description: Introduces interdisciplinary media processes, critical theory, formal communication design, color theory, skills in objective evaluation and critique, and how materials, processes, and context establish meaning.

courses.title: Print Media Digital Arts
courses.description: Examines application of print media in contemporary visual culture; explores its use in a fine art context. Introduces digital drawing, digital photo editing, and typographic layout to visually communicate expressive concepts. Laboratories, lectures. Repeatable once for 8 maximum credits.Repeatable 1 time for a maximum of 8 credits

courses.title: Time-Based Digital Arts
courses.description: Explores the notion of time as a medium in relation to contemporary art through which concepts of sequence, narration, scoring, and motion are expressed. Laboratories, lectures. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.Repeatable 1 time for a maximum of 8 credits

courses.title: Interactive Digital Arts
courses.description: Introduces resources that the computer offers the artist. Concentrates on animation, interaction, and the web as expressive mediums. Laboratories, lectures. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits.Repeatable 1 time for a maximum of 8 credits

courses.title: Special Studies: [Topic]
courses.description: Repeatable when the topic changes.Repeatable 99 times when topic changes

courses.title: Accounting: Language of Business Decisions
courses.description: How the accounting model reflects business transactions or events. Interpretation and analysis of financial statements. Understanding cost and revenue information, organization, and decisions.

courses.title: Marketing: Creating Value for Customers
courses.description: Market analysis, target customer identification, and development of marketing-mix strategies to deliver superior customer value and contribute to the performance of the organization.

courses.title: Web Applications Development I
courses.description: Fundamentals of web application development using open-source software tools and technologies (Unix, Git), client-side frameworks, server-side programming (Node.js, PHP), model-view-controller pattern, data storage and APIs, cloud hosting.
courses.requisites: CS 111 with a grade of B- or higher.

courses.title: Introduction to Web Programming
courses.description: Project-based approach to learning computer programming by building interactive web pages using JavaScript and HTML. Programming concepts including structured and object-oriented program design. CS 110 recommended preparation.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming and Problem Solving
courses.description: Computational problem solving, algorithm design, data structures, and programming using a multi-paradigm programming language. Introduces techniques for program design, testing, and debugging.

courses.title: Computer Science I-III
courses.description: Basic concepts and practices of computer science. Topics include algorithmic problem solving, levels of abstraction, object-oriented design and programming, software organization, analysis of algorithm and data structures. Sequence with CS 210, CS 211.

courses.title: Computer Science II
courses.description: Basic concepts and practices of computer science. Topics include algorithmic problem solving, levels of abstraction, object-oriented design and programming, software organization, analysis of algorithm and data structures. Sequence with CS 210, CS 212.

courses.title: Software Methodology I
courses.description: Technical and nontechnical aspects of software development, including specification, planning, design, development, management and maintenance of software projects. Student teams complete projects.

courses.title: Contemporary Economic Issues
courses.description: Examines contemporary public policy using economic principles. Topics may include balanced budgets and tax reform, unemployment, health care, poverty and income redistribution, environmental policy, and international trade policy.

courses.title: Introduction to Economic Analysis: Microeconomics
courses.description: Examines how consumers, firms, and governments make decisions when facing scarce resources and how those decisions affect market outcomes, such as prices and output. MATH 111 recommended.

courses.title: Introduction to Economic Analysis: Macroeconomics
courses.description: Examines the aggregate activity of a market economy, the problems that arise, such as inflation and unemployment, and how the government can use macroeconomic policy to address these problems. EC 201 recommended.

courses.title: Resource and Environmental Economic Issues
courses.description: Economic analysis of replenishable and nonreplenishable natural resources; environmental issues and policies.

courses.title: Issues in Industrial Organization
courses.description: Topics may include analysis of market power, trends in industrial structure, the role of advertising, pricing policies and inflation, impact of social regulation (e.g., OSHA, EPA), and international comparisons.

courses.title: International Economic Issues
courses.description: Exchange across international boundaries, theory of comparative advantage, balance of payments and adjustments, international financial movements, exchange rates and international financial institutions, trade restrictions and policy.

courses.title: Allocating Scarce Environmental Resources
courses.description: Considerations for the design of environmental and natural resources policies and regulations: balancing society's preferences and the costs of environmental protection and resource conservation.

courses.title: Environmental Ethics
courses.description: Key concepts and various moral views surveyed; includes anthropocentrism, individualism, ecocentrism, deep ecology, and ecofeminism. Exploration includes case studies and theory.

courses.title: Ecological Footprint of Energy Generation
courses.description: Detailed study of the ecological consequences of all forms of energy generation including fossil fuels and alternative energy sources. Open to environmental science, environmental studies, and planning, public policy and management majors only.

courses.title: Environmental Justice
courses.description: Environmental justice and its impact on current decisions. Focus on civil rights law, perception of risk, and relation of sustainability and equity.

courses.title: Sustainability
courses.description: Examines the evolution of the concept of sustainability and its complex and sometimes problematic uses among scholars, policymakers, environmentalists, and businesses.Requisites:Pre- or coreq: ENVS 201; junior or senior standing.

courses.title: Sustainable Agriculture
courses.description: Examines sustainability issues in agricultural production and current food systems. Focuses on environmental aspects of seed, water, soil, energy, and pest management.

courses.title: Special Studies: [Topic]
courses.description: Repeatable.Repeatable 99 times

courses.title: Urban Farm
courses.description: Experimentation with food production in the city; rebuilding urban soils; farm animal-plant relationships; nutrient cycles. Cooperative food production and distribution; use of appropriate technologies. Repeatable.Repeatable 99 times

courses.title: Experimental Course: [Topic]
courses.description: Repeatable.Repeatable 99 times

courses.title: Experimental Course: [Topic]
courses.description: Repeatable when the topic changes. Recent topics include Strategic Environmental Management, Technology and Innovation Management.Repeatable 99 times when topic changes

courses.title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Understanding of the historical and socio-economic context of entrepreneurship and how entrepreneurial ecosystems function and grow; fundamentals of entrepreneurship and business model development.

courses.title: Implementing Entrepreneurial Strategies
courses.description: Fundamentals of entrepreneurship are applied to solve actual problems for real companies. Students will gain a thorough understanding of project management processes (agile, lean six sigma, sprints, etc.) and learn how to effectively execute a project from inception to final deliverable.

courses.title: Music, Money, and the Law
courses.description: Explores theory and history of relationship between money and music, and corresponding laws that govern and shape that relationship. Topics include copyright, contract rights, media distribution technology, marketing, unions.

courses.title: Digital Audio Workstation Tech I-III
courses.description: Explores advanced techniques of mixing, the principles of mastering, and digital distribution using a computer. Series with MUS 476 and MUS 477. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits. Laboratory fee.

courses.title: Audio Recording Techniques I-III
courses.description: Focuses on the production concepts and techniques necessary to produce a full-length, professional-quality compact disc. Sequence with MUS 480, MUS 481. Laboratory fee.

courses.title: Audio Recording Techniques I,II
courses.description: Application of advanced recording techniques.  Sequence with MUS 480, MUS 482. Laboratory fee.

courses.title: Introduction to Product Design
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the Product Design profession and its cultural relevance. Lectures, reading and projects convey theory (critical thinking), designers (history), design methods (CAD, drawing, building), and storytelling (documentation / presentation) to give a foundation in product innovation, creation, and portfolio generation.

courses.title: Design Process
courses.description: Introduces design processes, from theoretical to professional, using readings, guest lectures, and experimental new structures.

courses.title: Advanced Studio III
courses.description: Design studio focuses on corporate questions that are explored through active design development. Questions may relate to issues of user interface, sustainability, or societal problems. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.
courses.requisites: PD 302, PD 340.Repeatable 2 times for a maximum of 12 credits

courses.title: Physics Behind the Internet
courses.description: How discoveries in 20th-century physics mesh to drive modern telecommunications. Topics include electron mobility in matter, the development of transistors and semiconductors, lasers, and optical fibers.

courses.title: Physics of Energy and Environment
courses.description: Practical study of energy generation and environmental impact, including energy fundamentals, fossil fuel use, global warming, nuclear energy, and energy conservation.

courses.title: Solar and Other Renewable Energies
courses.description: Topics include photovoltaic cells, solar thermal power, passive solar heating, energy storage, geothermal energy, and wind energy.

courses.title: Introduction to the Nonprofit Sector
courses.description: Overview of the nonprofit sector includes its origin, growth, oversight, and varied elements. Examines theory and research into the effectiveness of nonprofit strategies and structures.

courses.title: Project Management
courses.description: Application of specific techniques that lead to projects being completed on time, within budget, and with appropriate quality.

courses.title: Impact Philanthropy
courses.description: Introduction to impact philanthropy and related topics. Evidence-based philanthropy, venture philanthropy, impact investing, social impact bonds, impact measurement, and policy environment.

courses.title: Introduction to Psychology II
courses.description: Introduction to the science and application of psychology. Emphasis will be placed on psychological concepts, theories, and principles related to: Personality, Social Psychology, Health and Well-Being, Motivation and Emotion, Disorders, Therapies, Lifespan Development, and related topics

courses.title: Scientific Thinking in Psychology
courses.description: Fundamentals in the empirical study of human behavior, including hypothesis formation, experiment design, behavioral data basics, and critical evaluation of scientific claims. Sequence with PSY 302, PSY 303.  Students may not register for PSY 301 after completing PSY 303.

courses.title: Cognition
courses.description: Major topics addressed in this class include perception, attention, memory, language, reasoning, and decision-making.

courses.title: Social Psychology
courses.description: Processes underlying social perception and social interaction. Topics include aggression, the self-concept, stereotyping and prejudice, conformity, persuasion, attraction, and helping.
courses.additional_info: Cultural Literacy: US: Difference, Inequality, Agency

courses.title: Culture and Mental Health
courses.description: Role of culture in the definition and maintenance of mental health and the definition and treatment of mental illness.
courses.additional_info: Social Science AreaCultural Literacy: US: Difference, Inequality, Agency

courses.title: Group Dynamics
courses.description: Topics in small-group dynamics, including decision-making, conflict, and changes over time in group structure and behavior.
